Yes. I'm updating this PR according to the discussion on #12830. Muxi's suggestions are still very useful regarding variable names, thanks!

Thank you for your pull request. Before we can look at your contribution, we need to ensure all contributors are covered by a Contributor License Agreement.

After the following items are addressed, please respond with a new comment here, and the automated system will re-verify.

* User @dgquintas isn't covered by a CLA. They will need to complete the form at https://identity.linuxfoundation.org/projects/cncf

_Regards,
The Linux Foundation CLA GitHub bot_

Thanks @muxi and @markdroth . This time the implementation should really follow the spec. In particular, we now separate `current_backoff` and `current_deadline`, in addition to the naming changes suggested by @muxi, that also make the variables names be consistent with the spec's pseudocode.

> Why make the caller do the comparison? Why not hide that detail?

You are right that this detail should be hidden by the backoff module since that is exactly what the backoff spec suggests. I was wrong on this point.

> What's the advantage of exposing the max() operation to the client.

Because the concept of connection timeout (for current connection) is separate from the concept of backoff (if the current connection fails). 

IMHO `min_connect_timeout` should not have been **defined** in the backoff spec and module; it should be more like **referred** in the backoff spec to demonstrate the backoff algorithm. `min_connect_timeout` is the minimum timeout that we are hoping to give **when making the connection attempt**, which is a configuration parameter for making connection, not for calculating backoff. Therefore referring to `min_connect_timeout` inside backoff is not quite clean. As you can tell by looking at backoff.cc, backoff->min_connect_timeout is only used for calculating the timeout, not related to backoff at all. Mixing and returning a connection timeout together with backoff deadline in a function called `backoff_step` is again confusing.

If we peel timeout apart from backoff, I think it will give advantage of the code being cleaner, easier to read , and potential flexibility like using different min_connect_timeout for different connection attempts but reusing the same backoff module for all of them.

But anyway, that takes time to implement and the benefits seems small at this time, so I am good with the current implementation 😄

I don't understand the problem here. The value passed to `grpc_connector_connect` is the time at which the current connection attempt should time out, and that is using the `current_deadline` field from the `grpc_backoff_deadlines` struct, which I think is correct. The value used to start the timer is the time at which we should start the next connection attempt, and that is using the `next_backoff_deadline` field from the `grpc_backoff_deadlines` struct, which also looks correct to me. Note that the timer will not be started until after the current connection attempt fails, and if `next_backoff_deadline` is in the past when that happens (because the connection attempt took longer to fail than the backoff duration), the timer will fire immediately, and we will immediately start the next connection attempt. --- *Comments from [Reviewable](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/13121)*
